data.title: Norodom Sihanouk
data.meta_description: News about Norodom Sihanouk, including commentary and archival articles published in The New York Times.
data.text:
Review: In ‘Don’t Think I’ve Forgotten,’ Cambodia’s Lost Generation of Pop Stars

Musicians of a thriving pop music scene in Cambodia that was brutally stamped out by the Khmer Rouge in the 1970s reclaim their place in the global youth culture of their era.

By A.O. Scott

A Spectacle of Mourning for a King in Cambodia

The reign of King Sihanouk, who died in October at the age of 89, spanned both the euphoria of independence from France and the terror of the Khmer Rouge.

By Thomas Fuller

IHT Rendezvous

The Bloodied Legacy of Cambodia’s Chameleon King

The legacy of King Norodom Sihanouk, who died Monday in Beijing at age 89, might be forever sealed and tarnished by his alliance with the hyper-communist Khmer Rouge movement that ravaged Cambodia from 1975 to 1979.

By Mark McDonald
